summary.text: Alert levels are the severity levels to be used with NeonAlert & NeonToast components to inform the user of the severity of a message.
Error level, use for indicating a problem that the user cannot recover from.
Information level, use for standard informational messages.
Success level, use for indicating successful actions.
Warning level, use for indicating a problem that the user can recover from.
Placement values for use with the NeonAlert component. This is used to describe the positioning of alerts on the screen.
Position alerts in the bottom left of the screen
Position alerts in the bottom right of the screen
Position alerts in the top left of the screen
Position alerts in the top right of the screen
Describes the available sizing options for NeonBadge.
An extra, extra large badge size, typically has a default of 80 rem.
An extra large badge size, typically has a default of 64 rem.
A large badge size, typically has a default of 48 rem.
A medium badge size, usually the default size. Which typically has a default of 40 rem.
A small badge size, typically has a default of 32 rem.
Describes the different sizes of NeonButton components.
Extra large buttons are by default 64 rem in size
Large buttons are by default 48 rem in size
Medium buttons are by default 40 rem in size
Small buttons are by default 32 rem in size
Describes the different NeonButton styles.
USED INTERNALLY: an input field style button. This is used as the button trigger for NeonSelect & NeonDatePicker for consistency with other form fields.

Outline buttons appear with a border & no background color. Outline buttons should be used for secondary actions
or alternate actions outside the main flow to minimise distraction for the user.
Solid buttons are solid color buttons. Use these for primary or secondary actions (usually low contrast color).

Text buttons appear as text without a background. Text buttons are usually used for icons buttons or secondary
actions.
Describes the different actions available for the interaction with the NeonChip component.
The Click action triggers a click event in the component.
The Remove action triggers the removal of the component. This can be used for filter chips.

Describes placement of dropdown related components like:
  • NeonSelect
  • NeonDropdownMenu
  • NeonDropdown

The placement has a primary placement (the first direction) & a secondary placement (the second direction). The primary placement is the location of the popup relative to the triggering element (e.g. the select button). With the secondary placement defining the alignment relative to the trigger. E.g. BottomLeft will open the dropdown below the trigger element with the left-hand edges aligned.

The placement utilities are smart & dynamic. They listen to resize events & aim for best effort based on where the dropdown is opened. E.g. in the case above with BottomLeft if there is not enough visible room to align the component to the left then it will try to align to the right & likewise if there is not enough space below the trigger it will align to the top (& reverse the option order in the case of a select).
Placement below trigger element, aligned to the left
Placement below trigger element, aligned to the right
Placement to the left of the trigger element, aligned to the bottom
Placement to the left of the trigger element, aligned to the top
Placement to the right of the trigger element, aligned to the bottom
Placement to the right of the trigger element, aligned to the top
Placement above trigger element, aligned to the left
Placement above trigger element, aligned to the right

Dropdown trigger style for describing the triggering element of dropdowns & selects like:
  • NeonSelect
  • NeonDropdownMenu
  • NeonDropdown
A circular NeonBadge
A style similar to NeonInput which is used as the default for a NeonSelect
A NeonButton in the solid color style
A square NeonBadge
A NeonButton in the text style
The core color palettes available for styling components in Neon. See the design section Color page for more details on color palettes.
Accent is an alternative brand accent palette used when multiple brand colors are required
Brand is the main brand color palette, this is useful for branded CTAs, text & controls.
Error can be used to convey issues/actions that are severe & that the user may not be able to recover from.

High contrast is a higher contrast palette than can be used for increased accessibility or for a stronger black &
white application.
Info can be used to convey informational context, e.g. notes & alerts
Low contrast is a more subtle neutral palette which can be used for secondary actions & supporting text.
Neutral is the base greyscale palette.
Primary is the main application color palette. For most applications this will be used by default.
Success can be used to convey successful actions.
Warn can be used to convey issues/actions that are less severe but may still impact the user.

Describes the horizontal positioning of certain elements in the context of a component. An example would be an icon
in a button or label as well as the label for a checkbox or switch.
Left horizontal positioning.
Right horizontal positioning.
Display input indicator OUTSIDE the adjacent input.
Display input indicator INSIDE the adjacent input.
Describes the supported HTML input modes that can be used with NeonInput & NeonNumber. This is used primarily for triggering keyboard context on mobile devices.
The decimal mode. Opens a numeric keyboard for decimal input.

The email mode. Allows the mobile device to provide an email optimised keyboard with email suggestions /
autocompletion.
The default - no context is provided.
The numeric mode. Opens a numeric keyboard for numeric input.
The search mode. Allows the mobile device to provide a keyboard optimised for search.
The telephone mode. Allows the mobile device to provide recent numbers / phone number search.
The text mode. Opens a text keyboard.
The url mode. Allows the mobile device to provide a URL optimised keyboard.
Corresponds to the HTML input types for use with NeonInput. NOTE: prefer the specific components for Number, Password, Date, File, Search fields.
Date input for selecting dates from a calendar. Use NeonDatePicker.
Date time input for selecting dates including a specific time.
Email input for entering email addresses.
File input for opening a file dialog. Use NeonDatePicker or NeonDropZone.
Number input for entering numeric values. Use NeonNumber
Password input for entering passwords. Use NeonPassword
Range input for a slider control. Use NeonSlider or NeonRangeSlider
Search input for searching. Use NeonSearch
Telephone number input.
Text input for single or multiline text input.
Time input.
URL input for entering web addresses.
The size options for the NeonLabel component.
Extra extra small, default is 16 rem.
Extra small, default is 20 rem.
Large, default is 44 rem.
Medium, default is 36 rem.
Small, default is 28 rem.

Describes the available gap options for the NeonInline & Neon Stack components, expanding on NeonSize to add a Zero
gap option.
The different modes that can be used in Neon. See Dark mode for more details.
Dark mode
Light mode
Match the user's selected system mode
The orientation options for the NeonCard & radio button components.
Horizontal orientation with content flowing across the page
Vertical orientation with content flowing down the page

Describes the different outline accessibility styles available in Neon. These are displayed when the component has focus. Generally these are internal use only with defaults provided for all interactive components. However, this can be provided for the NeonLink & NeonTooltip components to override the default when desired.
Apply a background color
Apply an outline border
Apply a bullet point
No outline style is displayed
Apply an underline, usually used for text, e.g. links
Placement directions used for placement of the NeonTooltip & NeonDrawer components when active.
Place the tooltip contents to the left of the trigger element.
Place the tooltip contents below the trigger element.
Place the tooltip contents to the right of the trigger element.
Place the tooltip contents above the trigger element.

Responsive breakpoints defined in Neon. These cover both smaller than & larger than cases for ultimate flexibility in defining responsive styles. See the responsiveness documentation for more details.
Defines NO breakpoint. This is only used for defining the global NeonGrid breakpoint layout.
Defines a desktop breakpoint of max-width: 1439px.
Defines a larger than desktop breakpoint of min-width: 1440px.
Defines a larger than mobile breakpoint of min-width: 415px.
Defines a larger than mobile large breakpoint of min-width: 768px.
Defines a larger than tablet breakpoint of min-width: 1024px.
Defines a mobile breakpoint of max-width: 414px.
Defines a large mobile breakpoint of max-width: 767px.
Defines a tablet breakpoint of max-width: 1023px.

Describes the available sizing options of most components. NOTE: Some components use a custom enum which expands on
the NeonSize options.
A large component size, typically has a default of 48 rem.
A medium component size, usually the default size. Which typically has a default of 40 rem.
A small component size, typically has a default of 32 rem.
Different sizes of the NeonSplashLoader component's animated icon.
Extra large size, typically has a default of 96 rem.
Large size, typically has a default of 48 rem.
Medium size, typically has a default of 40 rem.
Small size, typically has a default of 32 rem.
Input states which can be applied to Neon button & inputs to give user feedback.

Error state - indicates there was an erroneous action. Displays the error state of the component & blocks user
interaction.

Loading state - indicates there is a loading action blocking a component. Displays the loading state of the
component.
Default state - indicates the user can interact with the component

Success state - indicates there was a successful action & prevents user interaction with a component. Displays the
success state of the component & blocks user interaction.
Describes the available NeonSwitch styles.
Checkbox style - styles component as a traditional HTML checkbox.
Switch style - styles component as a switch button with on/off states.
The size options for the NeonToggleChip component.
Extra small, default is 24 rem.
Large, default is 48 rem.
Medium, default is 40 rem.
Small, default is 32 rem.
Describes the available NeonToggle styles.
Card style radio buttons for more detailed content
Traditional HTML radio button input style.
Toggle style which is a horizontal group of connected buttons with one active member.
Describes the available NeonTooltip styles.
Style for presenting longer, multi-line content.
Tooltip style for very short (single line) content.
Describes vertical positioning of NeonToast notifications.
Position centred at bottom of the screen.
Position centred at top of the screen.

readme.text:
![GitHub package.json version](https://img.shields.io/github/package-json/v/aotearoan/neon) ![npm bundle size (scoped)](https://img.shields.io/bundlephobia/minzip/@aotearoan/neon) ![GitHub last commit](https://img.shields.io/github/last-commit/aotearoan/neon) ![npm](https://img.shields.io/npm/dt/@aotearoan/neon) ![GitHub](https://img.shields.io/github/license/aotearoan/neon) ## Documentation & Demo Full documentation is available on the [demo site](https://aotearoan.github.io/neon/). ## Installation Install with NPM: 
npm install @aotearoan/neon
or yarn: 
yarn add @aotearoan/neon
## Usage ### Javascript/Typescript Import components and supporting classes like so: 
import { NeonButton } from '@aotearoan/neon';

export default defineComponent({
  name: 'SomeComponent',
  components: {
    NeonButton,
  },
  ...
});
### SASS To import the theme:
